Exergy analysis of a single cylinder DI diesel engine at various engine loads. Water/diesel/biodiesel emulsions with cerium oxide nanoparticle as fuel blends. Engine load and fuel type profoundly affected sustainability indices of the engine. B5 blend with 3 w/w% water and 90 ppm nanoparticles showed the best performance.

Keywords: Diesel/biodiesel fuel blend Cerium oxide nanoparticles Engine load Exergy-based sustainability parameters Emulsion fuel Fuel additive
a b s t r a c t
This survey was aimed at determining exergy-based sustainability parameters of a single cylinder DI diesel engine in response to various fuel blends and engine loads at a fixed engine speed of 1000 rpm. Engine tests were conducted at four engine loads (25%–100%) using a 95% diesel + 5%biodiesel blend (B5) emulsified with water (3, 5, and 7 w/w%). All the prepared emulsions were stabilized with a 2:1 combination of Span 80 and Tween 80 (overall 7.5 w/w% surfactant). Two levels of cerium oxide nanoparticle concentrations (0 and 90 ppm) were also applied. The results showed that engine load and fuel type profoundly affected the exergy-based sustainability indices of the engine. Generally, increasing engine load steadily decreased exergy efficiency, while normalized exergy destruction declined by up to 75% under full load condition. Among the fuel blends prepared, the B5 blend containing 3 w/w% water and 90 ppm cerium oxide nanoparticles (B5W3m) showed the best exergy-based sustainability parameters at all the studied engine loads as its respective performance approached that of the basal petro-diesel. More specifically, among the fuel blends prepared the highest exergetic efficiency and the lowest normalized exergy destruction at full load condition were achieved using the selected fuel blend at 28.26% and 1.52, respectively. These values stood at 28.36% and 1.69 for neat diesel, respectively. However, the selected emulsified fuel blend represented a remarkably better environmental performance compared with diesel fuel. In conclusion, the B5W3m fuel blend might be effectively applied as substitute to mineral diesel fuel without any change in the existing engine structure.

However, the major drawback of diesel engines is the higher NOx, SOx, and particulate matter (PM) emissions, portraying them as one of the main culprits of the environmental and human health concerns faced today. On the other hand, the volatile petro-diesel price and its reservoirs depletion have developed the thrust in search of environmentally-clean and economicallyviable alternative fuels for diesel engines [2]. To surmount these issues, researches have been directed towards biodiesel in order to find a sustainable and affordable substitute for diesel fuel during the past decade. Despite the fact that biodiesel is renewable, biodegradable, non-toxic, and sulfur-free fuel [3], but it suffers from several deficiencies like lower calorific value, higher viscosity, poorer cold flow properties, higher pour point, lower volatility, and lower oxidation stability compared with mineral diesel.
In general, original vegetable oils, animal fats, non-edible oils, waste vegetable oil, and algae can be used as feedstocks for biodiesel production [4]. However, it is impossible to replace all the diesel fuel demanded worldwide using biodiesel obtained from the above-mentioned feedstocks because of food vs. fuel debate, financial and environmental considerations, resources constraints, etc. [4]. In order to offset this defect and to mask the abovementioned biodiesel disadvantages, partial replacement of petroldiesel up to 5% by using biodiesel obtained from waste-oriented oils could be put forward as an eco-friendly and cost-effective strategy for the next few decades to achieve a relatively cleaner combustion.
In this regard, a significant amount of research efforts can be found in the literature on the performance assessment and pollutant emission of diesel engine operating on various diesel/biodiesel blends [5–8]. Although biodiesel addition to diesel substantially reduces HC, CO, PM, and smoke emissions, but there is no unanimous agreement on the reduction of NOx emission [1]. In fact, biodiesel addition into diesel could generally increase NOx emission due to the higher combustion temperature, prolonged ignition delay, and larger oxygen content. To address the increased NOx emission, various methods like exhaust gas recirculation and
Please cite this article in press as: Aghbashlo M et al. A novel emulsion fuel co improve diesel engines performance and reduce exhaust emissions: Part II – E
engine design alteration have been implemented during the past few decades. Unfortunately, even if these methods decrease NOx emission, they concurrently increase smoke and PM emissions [9].
Another strategy which could to a great extent reduce NOx emission is through introducing water into combustion chamber by different methods, i.e., as an additive through forming water/ diesel emulsion in the presence of a stabilizer, spraying water into the cylinder individually, and fumigating water in the inducted air. It is well-documented that the first strategy can effectively reduce the emission of NOx and smoke via encapsulating water within the emulsion by using a suitable surfactant. Notably, not only this method does not negatively affect fuel consumption and engine thermal efficiency but also there is no contact between the engine surfaces and the water incorporated [10,11].
In fact, water/diesel emulsion reduces the harmful pollutants and improves the combustion efficiency by ‘micro-explosion’ phenomena resulted from the varied volatility of the diesel fuel and water. This in turns results in ‘secondary atomization’ phenomenon by breaking the injected fuel droplets into fine ones, leading to the fast vaporization of fuel and its better mixing with the intake air [10–12]. In spite of its advantages however, unfortunately this technique adversely prolongs ignition delay, leading to high pre-mixed combustion rate, peak pressure, and heat rejection rate as well as harsh engine operation [13]. This problem can be greatly overcome by incorporating a small amount of metallic/ non-metallic nanoadditives in order to shorten ignition delay [14–16]. Although promising results have been reported, it is still crucial to scrutinize the potentials of water/diesel/biodiesel emulsion fuel containing nanoadditives from productivity and sustainability perspectives through the application of advanced engineering tools like energy and exergy analyses.
Traditional energy analysis based on the first law of thermodynamics cannot be applied to find the harmony between energy generation/consumption and environmental impacts [17,18]. On the contrary, exergy-based indicators can remediate this shortcoming by providing useful information on the irreversibility aspects (availability losses) of energy conversion systems [19].

Due to this reason, numerous research works have been carried out on the use of exergy concept for analyzing and improving internal combustion (IC) engines operating on various renewable and nonrenewable fuels and their blends. For instance, Debnath et al. [20] performed exergy analysis for a diesel engine running with waterin-biodiesel (palm oil methyl ester) emulsion at different compression ratios and injection timings. In another study, Morsy [21] assessed the exergetic performance of a DI diesel engine fumigated with ethanol/water mixtures as a secondary fuel to diesel. In the same year, Aghbashlo et al. [22] analyzed a DI diesel engine working with diesel/biodiesel blends (B5) including different quantities of expanded polystyrene using the exergy concept. Later, Bora and Saha [23] attempted to carry out exergy analysis for a biogas powered dual fuel diesel engine operating on emulsified rice bran biodiesel as basal fuel at various compression ratio and injection timing. Recently, Aghbashlo et al. [24] also evaluated the effect of amide-functionalized multiwall carbon nanotubes in diesel/biodiesel fuel blends on the exergetic performance of a DI diesel engine.
According to the outcomes of the above-mentioned surveys, the exergy concept could undoubtedly pave the way towards efficient and sustainable combustion processes. Although a large number of studies have been devoted to applying exergy concept for performance analysis of diesel running on various neat and blended fuels [20–24], to the best of our knowledge the exergetic performance of diesel engine operating on water/diesel/biodiesel emulsion fuel containing nanoadditives has not yet been presented. Therefore, the current survey was aimed at exergetically analyzing a DI diesel engine working with various water/diesel/biodiesel emulsion fuels containing cerium oxide nanoparticles. It is believed that the findings of the present survey could be of intense interest in the diesel fuel formulation domain and will be in line with the goals of sustainable energy development.

sections.heading: 2.1. Biodiesel production
sections.text: The biodiesel used in this study was prepared from waste cooking oil (WCO). The transesterification process of the pre-treated WCO was carried out using methanol in the presence of potassium hydroxide as catalyst. The mixture was agitated mechanically for 1 h at 60 C. The resultant slurry was then left for 1 h in order to separate methanol–biodiesel by gravity. The produced methyl esters were washed with water three times. Thereafter, the obtained biodiesel was heated at 80 C in order to remove the absorbed water.

sections.heading: 2.2. Fuel samples preparation
sections.text: The water/diesel/biodiesel emulsion fuels were prepared by adding three levels of deionized water, i.e., 3%, 5%, and 7% w/w into 1 L of B5 in order to obtain B5W3, B5W5, and B5W7, respectively. Prior to water incorporation, 75 mL of Tween 80 and Span 80 blend was added to B5. Tween 80 to Span 80 mass ratio was 1:2. In continuation, 90 ppm cerium oxide nanoparticle was added to the obtained emulsion fuels in order to prepare B5W3m, B5W5m, and B5W7m, respectively. A Polytron homogenizer (Switzerland) was employed for preparing the emulsion fuels. Homogenization was carried out for 15 min at room temperature. A total of 8 fuel blends including neat diesel, B5, B5W3, B5W5, B5W7, B5W3m, B5W5m, and B5W7m were considered for engine tests.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
The rates of fuel energy and exergy of the DI diesel engine as affected by various fuel blends and engine loads at a fixed engine speed of 1000 rpm are manifested in Figs. 3 and 4, respectively. The fuel energy rate ranged from a minimum value of 1.76 kW to a maximum value of 11.36 kW, while the fuel exergy rate was
Please cite this article in press as: Aghbashlo M et al. A novel emulsion fuel co improve diesel engines performance and reduce exhaust emissions: Part II – E
found to be ranging from 1.89 kW to 12.14 kW under the different experimental conditions investigated. Obviously, the fuel energy and exergy rates increased gradually with increasing engine load due to increments in fuel consumption at higher engine loads. Moreover, both the energy and exergy values of the fuel consumed by the engine at a given engine load had a similar trend. However, the fuel exergy rate was slightly higher than its energy rate counterpart owing to the fact that the quality factor (u) of all the prepared fuels was higher than 1. It should also be noted that the energy and exergy rates of the fuel combusted by the engine throughout this study did not represent a clear trend with fuel type. This could be attributed to the ill-defined physiochemical and combustion characteristics of the prepared emulsion fuels during injection and ignition. Overall, the fuel energy and exergy rates could not be applied to make decision on the efficiency and sustainability of combustion process without including the work produced and the exergy destroyed in the computations.
Fig. 5 shows the effects of fuel type and engine load on the thermal efficiency of the DI diesel engine at a fixed engine speed of 1000 rpm. The engine thermal efficiency varied from a minimum value of 20.94% to a maximum value of 34.78%. It is clear from this figure that increasing engine load decreased the engine thermal efficiency. This could be attributed to the fact the engine thermal efficiency is inversely proportional to the fuel energy rate as given by Eq. (13). Moreover, increasing engine load drastically increased thermal and frictional losses, lowering the ratio of the produced shaft work to the fuel spent. The substitution of a portion of neat diesel with biodiesel deteriorated the engine thermal efficiency under different engine loads due to the lower calorific value of biodiesel compared with mineral diesel.
Surprisingly, water incorporation into B5 particularly 3% water, dramatically improved the engine thermal efficiency. This could be ascribed to the beneficial effect of water in promoting a phenomenon called ‘micro-explosion’. As previously elaborated,

This in turn enhanced the fuel evaporation rate and improved the fuel-air mixing process. Nevertheless, water inclusion beyond 3% declined the engine thermal efficiency owing to the unfavorable effects of higher amounts of water previously reported including longer ignition delay and lower engine temperature [31]. The lower calorific value of the prepared emulsion fuels could also be mentioned as a reason for this finding (Table 3). Furthermore, applying cerium oxide nanoparticles in the fuel blends remarkably increased the engine thermal efficiency at all levels of water addition, particularly 3% water. In fact, the engine thermal efficiency during working with neat diesel was substantially higher than the other prepared fuel blends under different engine loads, expect for B5W3m.
This occurred due to the fact that the applied metal-based nanoparticles positively catalyzed the combustion reaction due to having a large surface area/volume ratio [32], propelling the fuel burning process towards the stoichiometric chemical reaction. The secondary atomization phenomenon must also have further enhanced reactive surfaces of the nanoparticles, resulting in higher chemical reactivity [32]. Moreover, the catalytic activity of the metal-based additives could have improved the positive effects of the ‘micro-explosion’ phenomenon.
Fig. 6 indicates the exergy destruction rate (irreversibility rate) of the DI diesel engine varied with fuel type and engine load at a
Please cite this article in press as: Aghbashlo M et al. A novel emulsion fuel co improve diesel engines performance and reduce exhaust emissions: Part II – E
constant engine speed of 1000 rpm. The maximum exergy destruction rate was 5.60 kW for B5W5m at full load condition, while the minimum value was 1.02 kW for B5W3m at 25% of full load condition. Clearly, the majority of the fuel exergy supplied to the chamber was destroyed at elevated engine loads, attributing to intensive heat transfer, higher mechanical friction, and severe combustion reaction. More specifically, increasing engine load enhanced the cylinder temperature due to enhanced fuel consumption. This is turn intensified the inherently irreversible processes such as heat loss to the coolant and ambient, thermochemical conversion, and air-pollutant mixing. Exergy destruction rate of the engine could not be clearly correlated with the fuel type. This could be related to the poor correlation between the fuel type and the fuel exergy rate (fuel consumption rate), as explained previously. Even though the exergy destruction rate could perfectly reflect the availability loss during the combustion process, but this criterion alone cannot be an ideal performance index to make decisions on the efficiency and sustainability of various operating conditions and fuel types. On the contrary, the normalized exergy destruction could be effectively applied to find the most thermodynamically-efficient and environmentally-benign experimental conditions by taking into account the exergy destruction rate during combustion process as well as the exergy of the shaft work attained.

Increasing engine load from 25% to 75% of full load condition increased the normalized exergy destruction due to an increase in the exergy destruction rate. However, increasing engine load from 75% to 100% decreased the normalized exergy destruction. Although increasing engine load from 75% to 100% drastically augmented the exergy destruction rate, but the useful work increment dominated the increased exergy destruction rate. Among the fuels applied, neat diesel and B5W3m had the lowest normalized exergy destruction, showing their suitability for the shaft work production from the exergetic viewpoint.
Furthermore, increasing water content beyond 3% dramatically increased the normalized exergy destruction because of the reduced shaft work at higher water contents. However, the normalized exergy destruction was profoundly influenced by nanoparticle addition into the fuel emulsions. This occurred due to the fact that metal-based additives could react with water at higher temperatures prevailed in the combustion process, resulting in molecular hydrogen production and, consequently, promoting the engine performance [33]. This could also be attributed to the unique physical properties of nanoparticles, i.e., high surface area/volume ratio. Basha and Anand [34] also highlighted that metal-based nanoadditive could act as catalyst and shorten the ignition delay.

Fig. 8 represents the effects of fuel type and engine load on exergy efficiency of the DI diesel engine at a constant engine speed of 1000 rpm. The lowest exergetic efficiency was found to be 19.60% for B5W7 at full load condition, while the highest exergetic efficiency was determined at 32.75% for neat diesel at 25% of full condition. Overall, increasing engine load destroyed the majority of the fuel exergy provided to the combustion chamber and, accordingly, lowered the exergy efficiency. The neat diesel fuel had the highest exergetic efficiency at all the engine loads, followed by the B5W3m emulsion fuel. However, B5W3m had better environmental performance compared with neat diesel as elaborated in the first part of this study [1]. Water addition up to 3% profoundly improved the exergy efficiency of the engine, while further incorporation of water had a detrimental effect on the exergy efficiency. This might be related to the fact that introducing a large amount of water into diesel/biodiesel emulsion increased the water droplet size to a great extent. A more coarse emulsion could be easily broken down during both injection and evaporation, devastating the production of more shaft work. In addition, exergy efficiency of the nanoparticle-blended emulsion fuels was extremely higher than that of the nanoparticle-devoid fuel blends because of the unique characteristics of the applied metal-based nanoadditive. In better words, cerium oxide nanoparticles could effectively prevail over the prolonged ignition delay resulted from water inclusion into diesel/biodiesel blends. Even though both normalized exergy destruction and exergy efficiency showed the suitability of the B5W3m emulsion fuel for achieving cleaner and efficient combustion process, but these exergetic indicators suggested different engine loads as optimal operational conditions. This showed the necessity of the application of advanced evolutionary- and knowledge-based approaches for optimizing engines operational variables and fuel compositions in order to find the most exergetically-sustainable conditions.
Fig. 9 represents the effects of fuel type and engine load on the exergetic sustainability index of the DI diesel engine at a constant engine speed of 1000 rpm. The exergetic sustainability index of the engine was found to be in the range of 1.24–1.49 and decreased as engine load elevated. This could be ascribed to a decrease in the exergy efficiency of the engine by increasing engine load, as explained previously. The best exergetically-sustainable fuel was neat diesel, followed by the B5W3m fuel emulsion. However, the latter showed the best environmental performance. This could be attributed to the mutual effect of ‘micro-explosion’ and subsequent secondary atomization process in the presence of the metal-based nanocatalyst [34]. Therefore, it should be highlighted that the exergy concept should be integrated with emission analysis or even economic data in order to find the most exergy-efficient, cost-effective, and eco-benign operational variables and fuel

Fig. 10 depicts the contribution of the shaft work, exergy destruction, and the other sources (exhaust air as well as heat loss to coolant and surroundings) to the fuel exergy supplied to the combustion chamber at full load condition for the engine speed of 1000 rpm. Clearly, the exergy destruction had the largest contribution to the total exergy due to several interconnected irreversible events like mechanical, chemical, thermochemical, and thermomechanical processes. Interestingly, the other sources stood in the second rank for the most applied fuel blends. Accordingly, future surveys should be performed focusing on minimizing availability loss during combustion process and on regenerating the exergy of hot flue gas in order to improve diesel engines exergetically.
A comparison was also carried out between two fuels selected (i.e., neat diesel and B5W3m fuel emulsion) on the basis of exergy efficiency and normalized exergy destruction. Although exergy destruction contributed to over 48% of the neat diesel fuel exergy, but this value was determined as low as about 43% for B5W3m emulsion fuel at full load condition. However, the exergetic contribution of the other sources to the B5W3m blend was higher than that of the neat diesel. sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: The exergy-based sustainability indices of a DI diesel engine as affected by different engine loads and fuel blends were evaluated using experimental data obtained at a constant engine speed of 1000 rpm. Experiments were conducted using B5 containing various amounts of water and cerium oxide nanoparticles. The exergy-based sustainability parameters of the diesel engine were remarkably influenced by the engine load and fuel type. The results of the exergy analysis revealed that B5 containing 3 w/w% water and 90 ppm cerium oxide nanoparticles could be a perfect alternative to neat diesel fuel in order to achieve cleaner and more efficient combustion processes. Even though the exergy efficiency of the selected fuel was somewhat lower than that of neat diesel, but its normalized exergy destruction was higher than diesel. Importantly, this fuel emulsion outperformed the neat diesel in terms of pollutant emissions. Therefore, the B5W3m emulsion fuel could assuredly replace mineral diesel due to its better exergetic and environmental performances. It should be noted that the cost-effectiveness and eco-benignity facets of this fuel blend must be additionally assessed using advanced exergy extensions such as exergoeconomic and exergoenvironmental analyses. Furthermore, the most economically- and environmentally-sound operational conditions and fuel blends should be explored by the use of emerging evolutionary- and knowledge-based optimization approaches.

metadata.abstractText: This survey was aimed at determining exergy-based sustainability parameters of a single cylinder DI diesel engine in response to various fuel blends and engine loads at a fixed engine speed of 1000 rpm. Engine tests were conducted at four engine loads (25%–100%) using a 95% diesel + 5%biodiesel blend (B5) emulsified with water (3, 5, and 7 w/w%). All the prepared emulsions were stabilized with a 2:1 combination of Span 80 and Tween 80 (overall 7.5 w/w% surfactant). Two levels of cerium oxide nanoparticle concentrations (0 and 90 ppm) were also applied. The results showed that engine load and fuel type profoundly affected the exergy-based sustainability indices of the engine. Generally, increasing engine load steadily decreased exergy efficiency, while normalized exergy destruction declined by up to 75% under full load condition. Among the fuel blends prepared, the B5 blend containing 3 w/w% water and 90 ppm cerium oxide nanoparticles (B5W3m) showed the best exergy-based sustainability parameters at all the studied engine loads as its respective performance approached that of the basal petro-diesel. More specifically, among the fuel blends prepared the highest exergetic efficiency and the lowest normalized exergy destruction at full load condition were achieved using the selected fuel blend at 28.26% and 1.52, respectively. These values stood at 28.36% and 1.69 for neat diesel, respectively. However, the selected emulsified fuel blend represented a remarkably better environmental performance compared with diesel fuel. In conclusion, the B5W3m fuel blend might be effectively applied as substitute to mineral diesel fuel without any change in the existing engine structure. 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
